questions.text: A common tactic used by scam callers is:

choices.text: Speaking slowly and politely with no requests
Creating urgency or fear to pressure you into action
Asking about your hobbies
Providing official documentation

questions.explanation: Scammers often use fear or urgency to rush you into making mistakes.

questions.text: Which of these is a red flag in a phone call?

choices.text: Call from a saved contact
Caller asks for personal or financial information immediately
You recognize the caller’s voice
Caller only leaves a voicemail

questions.explanation: Requests for sensitive info right away are a major red flag.

questions.text: How should you respond if an unknown caller claims to be from your bank?

choices.text: Give them your account number to verify
Hang up and call your bank using official numbers
Ask for their employee ID and trust it
Confirm details via text message

questions.explanation: Always contact your bank using trusted phone numbers or apps to verify.

questions.text: Scammers may often:

choices.text: Send an official-looking letter after the call
Pretend to be authorities or companies you know
Speak with your family first
Offer free technical support without asking for info

questions.explanation: Impersonation of authorities or trusted companies is common in phone scams.

questions.text: If a call makes you uncomfortable or seems suspicious, the safest step is:

choices.text: Continue talking politely
Hang up and report it if needed
Ask them to call back later
Call a friend to confirm

questions.explanation: Hanging up and reporting helps protect you and others from scams.

questions.text: A government scam call might claim:

choices.text: You won a contest legally registered
You owe unpaid taxes and must pay immediately
You are invited to a seminar
Your mail has arrived

questions.explanation: Scammers often use threats about taxes or legal action to scare victims.

questions.text: How can you verify a government-related call?

choices.text: Provide your social security or tax number to confirm
Hang up and contact the official agency directly using their published numbers
Click any link sent in a follow-up SMS
Call the number the caller provided

questions.explanation: Use official contact details from the agency's website to verify; don't use caller-provided numbers.

questions.text: Threats in a government scam call often include:

choices.text: Offering rewards and incentives
Arrest, fines, or account seizure if you don’t comply
Requests to meet in person casually
Asking about hobbies or surveys

questions.explanation: Scammers use fear of legal consequences to force quick payment or disclosure.

questions.text: Which is a safe practice when receiving a suspicious government call?

choices.text: Do not provide personal info and verify with the agency directly
Follow instructions to avoid trouble
Transfer the call to voicemail
Give minimal info and hope it’s fine

questions.explanation: Never give personal details over the phone; always verify independently.

questions.text: Red flags in government scam calls include:

choices.text: Caller’s phone number is official-looking
Calls demanding immediate payment over the phone
Caller refers to published procedures
Email confirmation from the agency

questions.explanation: Legitimate agencies rarely demand instant payments by phone.

questions.text: A common tech support scam tactic is:

choices.text: Offering free updates only
Claiming your computer is infected and needs immediate payment
Providing detailed, helpful advice without asking for info
Offering tutorials on software

questions.explanation: Scammers often falsely claim infection to get money or remote access.

questions.text: What should you never do during a suspicious tech support call?

choices.text: Take notes about the problem
Grant remote access to your computer
Ask questions for clarification
Hang up

questions.explanation: Granting remote access can let scammers install malware or steal data.

questions.text: Legitimate tech companies usually:

choices.text: Call randomly and demand money
Only provide support if you initiated contact
Ask for credit card numbers upfront
Use aggressive scare tactics

questions.explanation: Real companies generally respond to support requests you made, not unsolicited calls demanding payment.

questions.text: Which statement is a red flag in a tech support scam?

choices.text: “We noticed unusual activity on your account”
“Call now or your computer will be blocked forever”
“Check your system for updates”
“Please contact our support at your convenience”

questions.explanation: Scare tactics threatening permanent damage are often used by scammers.

questions.text: The safest action when you get a suspicious tech support call is:

choices.text: Follow their instructions to be safe
Hang up and contact your tech provider through official channels
Give a temporary password
Note their name and call back later

questions.explanation: Verify issues through official support channels rather than following unsolicited instructions.

questions.text: A common red flag in investment scam calls is:

choices.text: Offering verified financial advice through banks
Promising unusually high returns with no risk
Asking about your budget for retirement
Sending information via official email

questions.explanation: Guarantees of high returns with no risk are classic investment scam red flags.

questions.text: Which of these is a safe step when receiving an investment call?

choices.text: Invest immediately to secure gains
Research the company independently before acting
Share your bank details to open an account
Follow caller’s instructions for registration

questions.explanation: Independent research helps confirm whether an offer is legitimate.

questions.text: Scammers often:

choices.text: Recommend only government-approved investments
Pressure you to act fast and not think
Ask your opinion about the stock market
Suggest checking reviews online

questions.explanation: High-pressure tactics are used to stop you from researching or thinking carefully.

questions.text: Which is a suspicious offer?

choices.text: Long-term investment advice from your financial advisor
“Double your money in a week with this crypto deal”
Pension planning tips
Verified mutual fund options

questions.explanation: Promises of extreme, fast returns are typical signs of scams.

questions.text: The safest reaction to a suspicious crypto or investment call is:

choices.text: Give your bank info cautiously
Hang up and report or research independently
Ask for references only
Forward the offer to friends

questions.explanation: Stop communication, report suspicious calls, and verify offers through trusted sources.
